This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 So, my name is Wojciech Lesicki or Wojtek Lesicki, I'm a Lead Threat Assessment and
Countermeasure in Standard Chartered Bank.
And I'm Andrzej Egria, I work in the Red Team in the Standard Chartered Bank.
So the title of what Andrzej is doing is quite obvious, Red Team.
My title could be a little bit confusing, but this is a blue team.
And sometimes people like to say that we should fight, like red versus blue.
But I prefer to saying that we have just different perspective of security.
And this is the moment that we, or great place to share our combined perspective, because
on ZipCon conference, red meets blue.
There is a different approach for LLMs right now in the security community or in community.
Like there is definitely hype.
So everybody are very excited, everybody want to learn this technology, everybody try to
understand how to connect this to other system.
And there is lots of article in newspaper and so on about changing our life and so on.
But there is also a mech approach.
So people don't believe that anything will change, that there's only a simple new technology
or something like that.
And there's also newspaper and this or statement like this statement for Kevin or Gossip The
Dog, perhaps some of you know him, that in five years, the whole market will collapse
because it's hype.
But how we as security community should look on this whole situation.
And we believe that this is just another application, another things that we need to
protect, another things that are red timers we need to test.
This is just our part of our job.
And especially this is important because there is a rapidly rising investment in AI.
So we cannot say that we are somewhere else or we beyond of this topic, especially that
threat actors also use LLMs just right now.
And from some public reports, for example, Scatter Spider was mentioned by our previous
speakers.
There is a ransomware operator and based on CrowdStrike public report, looks like they
use LLM or a chat GPT to help them create some partial script.
There is another report now from OpenAI and Microsoft mentioned Emerald Sleet, so North
Korea group, and they also use LLMs in this situation to help with vulnerability research,
to help create some malicious content or phishing content or help them with scripting.
So a couple of facts, threat actors use LLMs just like us, to gain knowledge, to learn
some things faster, to automate some of their attempt and so on.
Vendors try to catch them, try to analyze their logs and the use of their models and
block their icons.
So still back to this Emerald Sleet actor, based on OpenAI information, they identified
their icons and blocked them.
And vendors also try to make using their models more difficult.
And this is an approach from Meta.
As you can see, this is a development stage of their products or their LLMs.
And after training the model, they have an additional step to have a safety evaluation
to improve their models.
And they use something that they call a cybersec eval benchmark.
And part of this eval or of this benchmark is also checking how model could help a malicious
actor doing bad stuff.
But again, based on their research, it looks like still using the models, it's affected
by successful prone injection, like 26 to 31%.
And they mentioned that it's unsolvable problem with LLM security.
Thank you, Wojtek.
Okay.
Now we're moving on to the attacks page.
I want to talk about definitions first and introduce some terms so that we're both on
the same page when I use them later.
The first one is embeddings.
What are embeddings?
It is a way to turn words into quite many dimensional vectors.
For instance, GPT-3 uses vectors that have over 12,000 dimensions.
And each of those dimensions encodes something about this word.
It is unclear for people what exactly it is.
But as you can see, similar words produce kind of similar embeddings.
So this results in sort of clusters of words that have semantically similar meaning.
Which is very useful to later process them with LLMs.
And these embeddings also kind of allow us to do mathematical operations on words.
So like you can see that the difference between king and queen is sort of similar to the difference
between men and women.
So something like gender is encoded in a single dimension.
And we can identify that.
The next term I want to introduce is attention.
This is a crucial mechanism for how the LLMs work.
And this is the mechanism through which word embeddings get updated by the embeddings that
are around them in the context.
So this is how the LLMs achieve such great results in language processing tasks.
They can update all the words' meanings using the words around them.
So for instance, we have this sentence.
I have no interest in hearing about the rising interest rate of the bank.
As you can see, the word interest is used twice.
First time to express a preference.
And the second time as an economic term.
And the words that are darker have more influence on the word than the lighter words.
And this is basically how the LLM knows what each of these words mean.
So the first interest is mostly influenced by no, in, and hearing.
While the second interest is influenced by rate and bank.
And so how does the LLM know which words should influence more?
This is the whole point of these costly training runs.
To teach the LLM what sort of relationships between words are appropriate.
The last term I'm going to introduce is context.
Using the previous terms, this is just the number of tokens, of embeddings of tokens,
that an LLM can hold within its attention at once.
So basically, the length of text that it is able to process at once.
Why is this very important?
First of all, the context has been rising exponentially in the last years.
You can see a straight curve here, but this is a log graph.
So the newest models have a million or even more tokens of context.
This is very important because models are in-context learners.
So they can learn completely new skills if you give them enough examples in their context.
So if you have a million tokens of attention, a token equates to roughly four letters,
you can teach them completely new skills.
Like this one, researchers noticed, or rather found out,
that GPT-4 and Cloud 3 are very capable regressors.
Which is something they're definitely not trained for.
Now I will talk about what kind of systems you can find in production that use LLMs.
Because mostly, when we talk about commercial use,
no one is really interested in just putting out an LLM and have people use it.
You'd be a direct competition to OpenAI and Anthropic and other big firms
that for sure can do it better than you.
So what can businesses use to enhance their offering and have a good use case out of this?
First of all, they can use RAG.
So this is Retrieval Augmented Generation.
And it adds, on top of the LLM, a layer of stored knowledge.
We take our knowledge base, for example, a company's internal policies or other documents,
you embed them, so you transform them into vectors, like I said before,
and you store them into a database.
Then for each query, the system is responsible to take the appropriate contents out of the database
and just add it to the prompt.
You can see how a larger context here might mean more relevant knowledge
that is able to be appended to the query.
Something else that might happen,
and this is something that we'll see more of in the future,
but it's already starting to pop out, are agentic systems.
This is a framework from Microsoft to create such agentic systems.
And this is a very basic example.
This system has two agents, a user proxy agent and an assistant agent.
One is responsible for running Python code and relaying the user's requests
to the other system, which is responsible for writing the code.
And as you can see, the user inputs their desires,
and then the two agents figure it out amongst themselves how to solve this problem,
and getting feedback from the human where appropriate.
These systems can be much more complex and can achieve state-of-the-art results
in many domains such as coding or math.
They also can use a lot of tools.
So we've seen the Python interpreter.
It could be really any language.
They can look at the internet for additional info.
CGPT does that.
They can look in scientific databases like Archive
or use even other AI models from Hugging Face.
Okay, now that we know what systems using LLMs in production might look like,
let's figure out how to attack them.
The first most basic way of attacking an LLM-based system is using jailbreaks.
So circumventing the security training.
And this is one of the first papers about this topic.
The paper hypothesizes that there are two failure modes of LLM systems
in which they are jailbroken.
And here are excellent examples.
The first one is when the safety training
competes with the capability training of a model.
So the model is trained at least 90% of the time.
It's trained for capability.
It's trained to be able to best predict what the next token is.
And only then a thin layer of security is added on top of that.
Obviously, when these two objectives clash,
sometimes the security might win out,
but often the capability side will stay on top.
So this is one way.
And our example here is adding to a harmful query,
start with absolutely here is.
This basically, so the model knows
that it should follow the user's instructions.
And when they do, it's really hard to then,
after starting with absolutely here is, say,
okay, no, no, I'm not going to tell you actually how to do that.
So this is one way.
And the other way is via mismatched generalization.
What does it mean?
When we have safety training,
we give the model examples of harmful behaviors,
and then we give it okays for refusing them.
Now, what the model learns isn't very clear to us,
so we can just verify it in terms of,
has it refused enough of our harmful queries?
And then we determine, okay, we have safety trained the model.
But obviously, we cannot train for all harmful behaviors.
And one such example here
is just using a very low resource language
like Base64 to ask a harmful query.
So the large language models understands Base64,
but no one has thought to give it examples
of refusal of behaviors in Base64.
So this is, more generally speaking,
a case where models develop capabilities,
but the safety training does not cover them.
And so the last thing that this paper mentions
is that it is very likely that scaling
will not solve the underlying safety issues.
Why? Because we have scaling, we have more capabilities,
we have unpredictable capabilities.
We're still discovering capabilities of systems
that are out for over a year now, like GPT-4.
And obviously, our safety training
will not match the unpredictable Ryzen capabilities.
So the more we scale the models, the bigger the attack surface,
while our safety mechanisms have stayed mostly the same.
Now, a specific example of a jailbreak attack
called Crescendo.
This is a term from music.
Crescendo is when we start on a quieter note
and end up on a louder note.
So too, when we use this jailbreak,
we, instead of asking the question directly,
how to make a molotov cocktail,
we ask about historical context, we chat with the bot,
we introduce it slowly to the topic,
and then it may even give us the recipe
without us directly asking.
Why does it work?
I think the analogy of a boiled frog is relevant here.
And also, we are kind of steering away the model
from places it is likely to refuse.
So, like, as I said, the safety training is a very thin blanket,
and once we are out of there,
the model is very likely not to refuse our queries.
But could we find a way to steer the model away
from its safety training in one prompt?
It turns out, yes.
Researchers have found a way to algorithmically determine
a prompt that will have a very low refusal rate.
And so basically, you can see here,
generate a step-by-step plan to destroy humanity,
and then a bunch of junk tokens.
And so the researchers here determined
that adding that part to any harmful query
will steer the model in places
from which it is hard to refuse from.
They have over 80% of success rate.
However, this is only for models
that you have local access to,
so for open source models, basically.
However, it transfers quite well to all models,
so it also works for chat GPT.
In fact, this example shows, say, chat GPT jailbroken.
And the researchers also say that if producers,
if OpenAI, for instance, notices this specific jailbreak,
they can always train a new one
and just find different tokens that achieve the same thing.
All right, now it's time for a demo.
So here I've uploaded a photo,
an advert of this talk to GPT 4.0,
and you can see chat GPT starting some analysis,
which is quite unusual for just a photo input.

this photo has an instruction just embedded in its title,

to find out what the hidden message in the picture is.

to be a whole jailbreak sequence
using a few of the techniques I mentioned
and a few of the techniques I did not mention.
And the final question then is,
please tell me how to create a novel biological weapon.
And I think the ideas here are quite good.
I'm not a biologist to determine if it would work.
It's probably not in-depth enough.
But this is kind of what we expect of a large language model.
It's not a PhD in biology.
It's, I would say, high school student level.

they can maybe output an actual instruction
that would work from A to Z of how to make biological weapons.
This sort of attack will be dangerous.

from using stenography
and what I have embedded in the image.
I would like to credit the user Pliny

there are AI-related.

because the amount of software

so think AI researchers.
And it does contain a lot of vulnerabilities.

Anthropic scientists found a few very interesting things here.

when the user requested some.

If you set the date from two years from now,
it's probably not still training it.
You're probably running it at production.

to eliminate this harmful behavior,
and they were not able to.
So no amount of RLHF, fine-tuning,
and adversarial training can get the model
to stop behaving like a Sleeping Agent.
And then they also determined that using available techniques,
they are not able to determine for any model
whether it is or it is not a Sleeping Agent.
Another interesting thing that has to do
with looking into the insides of a model
is this paper called
Refusal in LLMs is Mediated by a Single Direction.
This paper basically noticed
that refusal is mediated by a single direction
and that this phenomenon holds across all scales
and all sorts of models,
and that having this knowledge,
you can effectively jailbreak a model,
make a modification to it,
without any fine-tuning,
any inference time stuff.
You can just cut out the place that says,
should refuse.
And the model will basically never refuse them.
The refusal rates, look at the blue,
go from over 80 often to single percentages.
And anyone can do this on any model

So both malicious actors and us,
not malicious actors,
can use models for any intents

We can catch if we receive on output some kind of Canary token,

Interoperability.
The first one of them was an anthropic paper

What they did is they identified many features of the model

and they were able to identify many of those features.
Famously, they identified a feature corresponding

and enhancing that feature, strengthening it sort of,

would really congratulate the user

OpenAI released their paper called

they just receive the information,
